bibl.title: Letter to from [Henry Rose Carter] to Florence M. Read, September 8, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] critiques Connor's articles on mosquitoes, fish, and yellow fever. He credits Connor with the use of fish for mosquito control in recent yellow fever campaigns.

div1.head: Letter to from [Henry Rose Carter] to Florence M. Read, September 8, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
September 8, 1922.
Miss Florence M. Read,
Assistant Secretary,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Miss Read:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of September 5th., stating that Connor
would like to have a criticism on certain articles he had written, I
would say:

1/ I wrote him, at his request, a very full criticism on “Stego-
myia Indices and Their Value” prior to its publication.

I have never received the “Preliminary and Final Report on Merida,”
which I would be glad to have, nor the “Notes on the Use of Fresh Water
Fish as Consumers of Mosquito” etc., although I have one piece of his,
“Fish as Mosquito Destroyers,” reprinted from Natural History, No. 3, 1921.

His “Notes on Yellow Fever in Mexico” I received while at Geddes.
I acknowledged its receipt, but gave no detailed criticism thereof, ex-
cept simply to commend the paper, which it well deserved. I think I put
a Memorandum in a letter to Dr. Rose, stating that this was an excellent
paper.

a/ He makes only one statement of fact that I would question
(Page 4) “The campaign in Cuba extended over a period of 18 months be-
fore it was decided that the fever had been eliminated.” This campaign
was begun February 1901: I don't know when it was decided that the in-
fection was eliminated, but the last case reported occurred September of
the same year. It is questionable if the case at Colon of May 1906 was
yellow fever, but it was so reported (for executive purposes.) I am quite
sure that it was not

b/ On Page 5, in two places, “critical period” is used where he
clearly intended to use “critical number.” This is merely a verbal in-
advertance.

On the same page he implies he does not quite understand what I
mean by the term “critical number.” An examination of any of the articles
in which it is defined (as “The Mechanism of the Spontaneous Elimination
of Yellow Fever,” Annals Tropical Medicine and Parisitology. March 15/20) .
would, I think, clear this up. This is not, however, a matter of any im-
portance so far as this paper is concerned.

c) One may question the implied assumption, made here, that because
a Stegomyia breeding (of depositos) of 10% had proved to be a “safety in-
dex” for Guayaquil in 1919 it would be the same for all other places.

A town with a decidedly larger percentage of susceptible people
than Guayaquil then had would require a greater reduction of Stegomyia to
eliminate yellow fever than Guayaquil then did. In one with a much less
percentage of susceptible people a less reduction would suffice to do so.

It is to be noted that the index of breeding (house or depositos)
with unprotected depositos, is a fair measure of the number of (female) im-
agoes in flight and hence measures the risk of occurrence of yellow fever,
while, as Connor has well brought in his paper on Stegomyia Indices etc.,
the efficacy of our work in the control of yellow fever is measured, in-
versely, by the production of imagoes, which is taking place, which may
bear no relation to the amount of breeding.

d) The paper as a whole is good--very good. The part on Pages 1 and 2,
and in some other places, distinguishing between areas of “permanent en-
demicity” and foci not permanently endemic in such areas is true and well
expressed.

e) His discussion of “hacienda endemicity” (Pages 3 and 4) is also in-
teresting. Less clear than the above.

f Absolutely true is his statement of the relation of yellow fever
to the commercial history of the area and places in question, as is his com-
parison of the relative efficiency of adult immigrants and babies born in
the place in continuing infection in any locality. It is less clear than he could make it. It is questionable,
however, if his explanation of the diminution of infant mortality fol-
lowing the use of fish in the water containers would be accepted by a
number of tropical sanitarians--e. g. Juan Guiteras or old Chaille, if he
were alive. The absence of report of yellow fever among native children
is not proof that none is occurring.

g) I think too his explanation of the increase of Stegomyia produc-
tion during the early days of the rainy season is correct, although it
is one I have not thought of before.

h) His recommendation for fish in Stegomyia control, although strong,
is not by any means too strong. As you know, to him we owe the use of
fish for this purpose in our recent yellow fever campaigns.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, 2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
